<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[750, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 806, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
1 A thin solid disc of radius \(r\) and thickness \(z\) is attached to a thin axle. String is wrapped around the axle, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 114, 780, 388]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 405, 532, 422]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 435, 473, 452]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(m\) is attached to the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 465, 918, 513]]<|/det|>
The block is released from rest and falls downwards. The block has speed \(v\) when it has fallen through a distance \(h\) from the point of release. The value of \(v\) is determined using one light gate connected to a timer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 526, 569, 544]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(v\) is related to \(m\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 554, 576, 586]]<|/det|>
\[
\frac{h}{v^{2}}=\frac{\pi r^{2} z}{2 P Q m}+\frac{1}{P}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 593, 367, 610]]<|/det|>
where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 624, 696, 641]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(v\) and \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 654, 625, 672]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 685, 703, 702]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for \(P\) and \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 715, 383, 732]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 393, 763]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 776, 410, 791]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 805, 348, 821]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 834, 351, 850]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 864, 447, 880]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates a circuit containing capacitors. The circuit is connected with a capacitor of capacitance \(A\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 119, 626, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 440, 532, 457]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 471, 802, 488]]<|/det|>
Two capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), are connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 502, 635, 518]]<|/det|>
Initially, switch X and switch Z are closed and switch Y is open.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 533, 918, 580]]<|/det|>
Switches X and Z are opened. Switch Y is then closed. The maximum potential difference between P and Q is measured using the voltmeter. This procedure is repeated and the mean maximum potential difference \(V\) between P and Q is determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 594, 918, 626]]<|/det|>
The experiment is then repeated by changing the number \(n\) of capacitors, each of capacitance \(C\), connected in parallel between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 640, 571, 657]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(V\) and \(n\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 669, 567, 688]]<|/det|>
\[
E A=V(n C+A)
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 701, 581, 718]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 737, 144, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 730, 658, 758]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\frac{1}{V}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(n\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 768, 611, 785]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 875, 567, 893]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|> (b) Values of \(n\) and the two measured values of the maximum potential difference \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 121, 541, 136]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 153, 843, 460]]<|/det|>
\(n\)\(V_{1}/V\)\(V_{2}/V\)\(V/V\)\(\frac {1}{V}/V^{-1}\)
24.304.20
33.653.75
43.303.20
52.852.95
62.652.55
72.302.40
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 485, 918, 536]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \(V / V\) and \(\frac{1}{V} / V^{-1}\) in Table 2.1. Include the absolute uncertainties in \(V\) and \(\frac{1}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 549, 144, 566]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 549, 185, 566]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 541, 682, 571]]<|/det|> (c) (i) Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{V} / V^{-1}\) against \(n\). Include error bars for \(\frac{1}{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 579, 191, 596]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 577, 918, 610]]<|/det|> (ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 625, 188, 641]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 624, 918, 655]]<|/det|> (iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 191, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(iv) Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 212, 577, 230]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
y \text {-intercept = }
\)
